name: Noise Snke
description:
Noise Snke is an experimental Snake game that plays with data mutability by writing its board state directly to the sound card. The harsh sound that it creates highlights the fact that to a computer, data has no intrinsic meaning and can be used for any purpose.

Noise Snke was shown in Korea in 2016 at the Busan Indie Connect Festival. Game and write-up available here.

name: Drink Rink
description: Drink Rink is a bar and a game platform created with fellow Death By Audio Arcade members Mark Kleback and Anthony Marefat. Drinks are placed in special coozies that are seen by the cameras in the bar and used as game pieces for the game projected up onto surface. The bar runs several ambient games and cycles between them. The bar debuted at the Lwlvl chip tune festival in Brooklyn.

name: Genetic Combat
description:
This browser simulation attempts to create effective spaceship shooter AI using a genetic algorithm. The game itself is roughly based on Combat for the Atari 2600. When it starts, all ships are created with a completely randomized set of rules that govern their behavior. Once all of the ships in a given generation get a chance to compete, the ones that got the most kills (with a bonus for not dying themselves) are allowed to continue to the next generation and to have children. The children inherit the same set of behaviors that the parents had, but mutate them slightly: a value gets changed here and there, maybe a rule gets removed or a new one gets added. Even though these changes are random, over many generations the natural selection process selects for mutations that make them more effective pilots.

Full site here
Also avalaible on itch.io

name: Steam Users Don't Know What They Want
description:
This Chrome extension attempts make sense of Steam reviews by changing the text of any “do not recommend” review by a user who has played over 24 hours of the game to “I do not know what I want.”

Available for free on the Chrom Web Store.

name: ZipCalc!
description:
It’s the geolocative calculator of nobody's dreams! ZipCalc is a Hell Products and a joke about consumerism bought to its breaking point. It's a calculator that uses your phones GPS to find your zip code and adds it to the result.

The app was also an elaborate ploy to sneak in an easter egg asking my amazing partner Jane to marry me (she said yes!).

You can download it for free on the iOS app store.

name: Terminal Town
description:
Terminal town is a small, experimental puzzle that exists as a series of mysterious & personified command line tools. Every executable is a person or a tool and every folder is a place.

Players are tasked with opening the chest (a command line tool) in the center of town, and must learn how use the files that inhabit the town. There is no way to cheat. Everything in the game is just a file on the computer and can be treated as such.

While some experience with the terminal is helpful, the game does not require anything intense, and acts as a fun way to learn about a powerful part of the computer that many users are unfamiliar with.

It is available for free (Mac only).

name: Satan.Dance
description:
Satan.Dance is a cut-up web toy that stitches one word clips from the 90s police propaganda film Law Enforcement Guide To Satanic Cults

It was written in P5.js as part of a class I took at The School For Poetic Computation

It can be viewed at satan.dance

name: Intimate Codex
description:
Intimate Codex is an interactive non-linear text explorer that allows the user to traverse static text from a more first-person perspective. Books, poems, any other texts fed into it are broken up into passages, and the user can move between these passages by typing a particular word on screen. After submitting that word, they are brought to a new passage that shares that word.

By providing connections between different passages (and even entirely different works) based on keywords and randomness new narratives and meanings appear that can be vastly different from the original, linear stories.

Users are also encouraged to provide their own text, either from stories they like or their own original writing.

It can be downloaded for pay-what-you-want here: https://andymakes.itch.io/intimate-codex
Her Story.

name: The Easter Money
description:
The Easter Money is a low stakes gambling game designed by me & Jane Friedhoff for my family's 2016 Easter party. Your goal is to end the game with the most money cards (or at least as much as you started with).

The game is available for free as a print print-and-play in both color and b/w variants.

The illustrations on the color cards come from the New York Public Library's collection of public domain images.

name: Particle Mace
description:
Particle Mace is a game for Windows, Mac and iOS that pays homage to classic space shooters, but replaces the typical guns with an unruly physics-based weapon. Players control a tiny ship in an extremely hostile universe, and must defend themselves as long as possible from enemy ships and asteroids using a collection of trash particles tethered to the ship. To survive, players must carefully navigate around the many hazards while building up momentum to swing their weapon into foes or other players.

Inspired by twitchy arcade classics old and new, Particle Mace requires quick reflexes to stay alive, rewarding skilled players with high scores worth bragging about and giving new players a reason to hit restart. Graphically, the game uses abstracted visuals to create a striking play field combined with an entrancing procedural background.

More info at particlemace.com

name: Extreme Exorcism
description:
Extreme Exorcism is best described as a mixture of Braid and Super Crate Box. With each ghost you kill, another takes its place. You’ve been given access to a multitude of devastating weapons to rid the spirits--the only problem is, they copy your every attack.

Extreme Exorcism was born out of a small window of time we had between projects at Golden Ruby Games and became our first multi-console release.

The game is available on Steam for PC and Mac as well as PS3, PS4, Xbox One and Wii U

name: Musclebound Glory
description:
Musclebound Glory is a card and prop based party game about channeling your inner 80s action hero and crafting the perfect kill line. Players  hear a randomized action movie-style moment (including the villain being killed, the method of annihilation, and a twist), for which they must craft the perfect killer zinger. Players don berets, bandoliers, and Ray Bans to deliver their lines in style. The best line is decided by the group, and a new hero walks away from the explosion victorious, never turning back.

Musclebound Glory was shown at Come Out And Play 2014 in New York. We provided the deck and a carefully curated collection of props

Photo by Lia Bulaong

name: Hermit Crab In Space
description:
Originally created as part of the Sony sponsored PlayStation Mobile jam at the first Indiecade East, Hermit Crab In Space is the third game by Golden Ruby Games. One part Star Fox, one part Minecraft with a healthy dose of Captain Forever mixed in, Hermit Crab in Space won the IndieCade East GameJam in February 2013 and became a finalist at IndieCade the following year.

Players take the role of a hermit crab who has warped herself into the wrong sector and must cobble together a ship from the parts she blasts off her opponents. The game makes use of the touch screen and tactile buttons of the Sony Vita by allowing players to drag free-floating pieces to their ship and then select a button to activate them. This means that players create their ship and control scheme on the fly while playing.

Level and enemy design by Jane Friedhoff.

It is available on any PSM enabled device, but is intended to be played on the Vita. You can visit its PSM page here.

name: Worm Run
description:
You are Zeke Tallahassee, hapless space miner in the wrong place at the wrong time. Swipe on your touchscreen to move Zeke through an ever changing labyrinth all while being chased by a blood-thirsty, gigantic space Worm.

This was our second title at Golden Ruby Games and is currently available for iOS, Android, and Windows 8.

Our goal with this game was to create a control scheme for platformers that made sense for touch screens. We did this by adopting a gestural control scheme, rather than using clunky on-screen buttons, creating a tense, platforming experience actually designed for the device the game was being played on.

We also explored potential for a shared multiplayer experience that used iPhones as controllers when we ran a special four-person version of the game at the Gowanus Loft in Brooklyn.

A detailed description of how the procedural caves of Worm Run are created can be found here.

name: Doodle Defense
description:
Doodle Defense is a tower defense game that explores drawing as a means for game interaction and play. Players draw mazes and towers on a whiteboard with regular dry erase markers to stop projected foes. The game received 150% backing on Kickstarter and has been featured on IndieGames.com, Engadget, PC World, Ubergizmo, FastCo Design, UGO's list of the top video game Kickstarter projects and many other publications. It went on to be shown at Come Out And Play San Francisco, SF MOMA and the Dublin Science Gallery.

The game uses a camera and a projector in conjunction with the whiteboard to create a unique platform for play. The code and system is all my own, written in openFrameworks. The code is open source and can be viewed here.

All art in the game was done by Michelle Belickis

The game is available for free for whiteboard at doodledefense.com and for $2 on iPad

name: Find Me A Good One
description:
Find Me A Good One was created with Haitham Ennasr as our MFA thesis at Parsons The New School For Design, and was nominated as an Indiecade 2012 Finalist. It is available for free for PC or MAC here.

Find Me A Good One is a puzzle platformer that explores the sense of responsibility felt by players towards non-playing fictional characters. Although the brother in Find Me A Good One is clearly dependent on the player, it is up to the player to decide how much they want to help their sibling. While most games force the player to complete the task at hand in order to move on, Find Me A Good One allows the player to be diligent in their responsibility, or shirk it in order to further explore the dreamscape of the game. Because the system does not assign value to her actions, the player is left to judge their own actions and the effect they have on their virtual brother.

name: Destroy All Color
description:
The first game we released at Golden Ruby Games, Destroy All Color! is a fast-paced puzzle game played by using the iPhone's camera to find and use colors in the player's environment to destroy blocks on screen. The color choosen is then used in the subsequent levels, getting progressively more difficult. This makes for a unique and interesting game mechanic that combines the real world around the player with the digital puzzle of the game.

The game is available for iPhone and iPad.

name: Chase No Face
description:
Music video available here.

To shoot this video we programmed a series of masks in openFrameworks based on the face tracking code developed by Zach Lieberman and Daito Manabe using the FaceTracker library by Jason Saragih. No post-production effects were used: everything in the video was recorded live, using a hacked Kinect, a laptop, a projector and a DSLR camera. Some of the masks respond to movement and others respond to sound, creating an expressive outcome.

Bell is a Brooklyn-based independent musician.

Project team : Zach Lieberman (General direction, programming, video direction), Francisco Zamorano (Video direction, editing, programming), Andy Wallace (programming), Michelle Calabro (camera).

Photos and blurb by Francisco Zamorano

name: Horse_ebooks Talker
description:
The Horse_ebooks Talker deals with the id of the internet in the form of Twitter spam-bot extraordinaire, Horse_ebooks. This Twitter account advertises its products, but avoids the spam filters by grabbing random snippets of text from across the internet to appear ”alive” and in the process creates a compelling Dadaist tapestry of text from across the internet. This project tries to put these words back in the mouths of people by providing an augmented reality for anybody who looks at it, assigning them a random tweet to appear in a word balloon above their head.

This piece was featured in Open Concept Gallery's Smart Multimedia Festival.

name: All Cyrax Wants To Do Is Dance
description:
This simple HTML5 game was created as an exercise to learn jQuery, which I felt like I really ought to know. It tells the touching story of a cybernetic ninja who just wants to get down.

It can be played here.

name: Broken Mirror
description:
Broken Mirror is a camera application made in openFrameworks for the iPhone and iPad that takes the incoming camera feed and breaks it apart into a pixelated and constantly moving mosaic. Users can control the degree of abstraction in the image.

The app is 99 cents on the iOS store.

name: Sound Balls
description:
Created as my first year final project at Parsons, Sound Balls is a non-traditional method of sound generation that blends digital and analog elements in the form of a new audio toy. By manipulating a set of smart balls, users convert real world action into a fluid sound-scape that affords play and exploration. The system as a whole has two unique modes of interaction: Free Form and Singing Bowl, and users learn the rules of these systems while interacting with the balls. The balls themselves have unique attributes in both their hardware and the way the information from them is converted into sound. The information is gathered from each ball by an implanted micro-controller and sent wirelessly to a computer where it is interpreted in order to create the sound.

Design Document: Here

Base Station Arduino Code: Here

Ball Transmitter Arduino Code: Here

Transmitter Wiring Diagram: Here

Receiver openFrameworks Code: Here

SuperCollider Code: Here

name: ASCII Filter
description:
Demo video here

Based on an example project by Ben Fry packaged with the Processing language, this program takes incoming video and converts it to a text output. Pixels from the original image are considered as a group, and each letter is chosen based on both its overall weight as well as how well the shape fits the pixel group.

Ben Fry's original required the use of color to show the image, but to have a filter that felt authentic to ASCII art, I wanted to create one that worked in simple black and white.

Processing Source Code: Here

name: The Cuddle Cave
description: I worked with Jane Friedhoff and Dustin Hoffman to create a truck for the Lost Horizons Night Market called the Cuddle Cave. The Cave consisted of over 150 Ikea pillows in the back of a U-Haul dressed up with satin sheets that could only be gotten to via crawling through a small dark tunnel. Those brave enough to enter were treated with calming music and a soft respite from the cold autumn night outside.

name: Star Gaze
description:
This unique side-scroller was created by me and Haitham Ennasr as a proof of concept for our thesis at Parsons, exploring how game mechanics can make players feel responsible for NPCs. The player must pick their brother up at a train station late at night. On their way, they are given the chance to gaze up at the heavens to populate the sparse environment with constellations. However, this consumes an unknown amount of time and causes the player to run the risk of being late. There is no definite good or bad ending, but we observed that players tended to attach emotional weight to this relatively mundane situation.

It can be played online here.

name: Bounce Box
description:
Bounce Box is a simple but compelling game with just one rule: to keep the balls in the box. With each hit, the colors of the game shift, and as more balls get added, the visuals change more rapidly and the game becomes more difficult.

Bounce Box is free on the iOS store.

name: Fever Karaoke
description:
While interning with Eyebeam fellow David Jimison, I created animations and worked on the code of his project, Fever Karaoke. The piece was presented in a karaoke bar setting, but after participants selected a song, they were presented with mad-lib style word replacements, which would alter the words of the song as they sang.

These animations were projected behind the players and danced along with them. The animations are modular and code-driven so that they could be swapped and rearranged easily.

name: Isabelle Poppy & Bling
description:
As I was finishing up my undergrad degree, I was approached by musician Justin Braun, to create a music video to promote his new album, Relays From Home. After listening to the song a few times, though, I thought the music was better suited for a game.

The game uses a collage style and is split into three major sections, each of which takes inspiration from and is directly affected by the music.

This game was a Browser Game Pick at indieClick.com and was featured in Gamasutra's article Best of Indie Games: Falling Head Over Heels For Art Games.

It can be played for free on Kongregate.

name: Andy Wallace
description:
Andy Wallace is the Assistant Professor of Game Design at Long Island University Post Campus and an indpipendent digital artist and game designer. He received his MFA from Parsons The New School For Design in 2012 and worked for a few years at the tiny NYC game company Golden Ruby Games. He is also a founding member of the non-profit Death By Audio Arcade collective.

His work has been featured on Gamastutra.com, IndieGames.com, Engadget.com, PC World and CreativeApplications.net among others. His work has been shown througout the world including IndieCade, The Smithsonian American Museum Of Art, The Dublin Science Gallery, SF MoMA, MAGfest, The Busan Indie Connection Festival in Korea and The Museum of The Moving Image

He started coding on his parents' IBM 386 when he was 10, and shows no signs of stopping anytime soon. He loves the possibilities posed by the intersection of art and code. He can be reached at andy@andymakes.com or @andy_makes. I'm sure he'd love to hear from you.

Andy lives in NYC and can't wait to move into an apartment that allows dogs.
